---

Here are a few options for your LinkedIn post, ranging from a professional product announcement to a more personal "building in public" style. You can choose the one that best fits your voice.

### Option 1: The "Mission-Focused" Approach (Best for engagement)
*Focuses on the anxiety of preparedness and the solution you've built.*

**Headline:** **Survival planning usually takes hours. Now it takes seconds.**

I‚Äôve spent the last few weeks building an **AI-powered Emergency Planner** designed to help civilians survive the unthinkable.

Most people know they *should* have a plan for natural disasters or civil unrest, but they don't know where to start. The lists are overwhelming, and the advice is generic.

I wanted to fix that.

My new app generates a bespoke **Mission Report** based on your specific location, family size, and threat vectors. It‚Äôs not just a checklist; it‚Äôs a tactical survival engine that gives you:
‚úÖ Real-time threat analysis & risk assessment
‚úÖ Custom evacuation routes (Vehicle vs. On-Foot)
‚úÖ Automated inventory & calorie rationing for your squad
‚úÖ AI-generated survival protocols powered by Gemini 1.5 Flash

I‚Äôm opening up a small group for **early free access** to test the system and give feedback.

**Want in? Drop a "Survival" in the comments (or DM me), and I'll send you the access code.**

#Survival #AI #BuildInPublic #EmergencyPrep #TechForGood

---

### Option 2: The "Developer/Tech" Approach
*Focuses on the technology and the "cool factor" of the build.*

**Headline:** **I built a tactical survival engine with Next.js and Gemini AI.**

I‚Äôm excited to unveil a project I‚Äôve been hacking on: **Emergency Planner**.

It‚Äôs an AI-driven application that takes the guesswork out of disaster preparedness. Instead of generic advice, it uses the Gemini 1.5 Flash engine to model threat scenarios and generate logistic plans tailored to your exact geolocation and household size.

**Core Features:**
üõ† **Smart Logistics:** Auto-calculated gear lists with cost estimates and priority filters.
üó∫Ô∏è **Route Intelligence:** Maps integration for evacuation routes with danger level assessments.
üß† **Skill Gaps:** Identifies critical skills your group needs to learn based on likely local threats.

I‚Äôm looking for beta testers to stress-test the planning engine.

**If you want early access (free forever for early testers), comment below and I'll send you the link.**

#NextJS #AI #GeminiAI #SoftwareEngineering #BetaTest

---

### Option 3: Short & Punchy (Best for mobile scrolling)

**Headline:** **Who has a real plan for the next emergency?** üôã‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

I just finished building a new app that uses AI to generate custom disaster plans for you and your family in seconds.

It covers everything:
*   üìç Evacuation routes from your home
*   üéí Custom gear loadouts (with costs)
*   üçû Ration planning
*   ‚ö†Ô∏è Local threat analysis

I‚Äôm looking for 10-20 people to try it out for free and tell me what they think.

**Comment "Me" below if you want early access!**

#DisasterPrep #AI #Startup #ProductLaunch

---

### üí° Tips for posting:
1.  **Add a Screenshot/Video:** Since your UI looks great (the "Mission Report" dashboard with the dark tactical theme), definitely attach a screenshot or a short screen recording of the app generating a plan. Visuals of the map or the "Readiness Score" gauge will stop the scroll.
2.  **Engage with Comments:** LinkedIn's algorithm loves when you reply to comments. If people say "Survival," reply with "Sent!" or "Check your DMs."
3.  **Tagging:** If you used specific tech (like Vercel, Supabase, or Google for Gemini), tagging them can sometimes get you a repost.

---

Given the "Dark Mode Tactical" aesthetic of your app (Slate `#0f172a` background with Gold `#eab308` accents), a high-contrast, data-rich banner will stop the scroll best. LinkedIn users respond well to "proof of work," so showing the actual UI is better than a generic stock photo.

Here are 3 concepts you can create (even just by taking screenshots):

### 1. The "Command Center" (Best for Authority)
**Concept:** A wide shot of the **Mission Report** dashboard on a laptop screen or monitor, slightly angled.
*   **Focus:** Center the image on the **Readiness Score** (that gauge/score is visually catchy) and the **Evacuation Map**.
*   **Overlay:** Add a subtle vignette so the bright yellow accent colors pop.
*   **Why it works:** It looks like a professional tool, not a toy. It immediately answers "what does it do?"‚Äîit gives you a plan and a map.

### 2. The "Before & After" Split (Best for Storytelling)
**Concept:** A split image divided by a diagonal line.
*   **Left Side (The Problem):** A blurry, chaotic background (maybe a storm or just a messy pile of gear) with the text "Unprepared?" in white.
*   **Right Side (The Solution):** A crisp, clean screenshot of your **Gear Checklist** UI showing the "Items Ready" progress bar and the organized list.
*   **Why it works:** It visualizes the peace of mind your app provides‚Äîturning chaos into order.

### 3. The "Product Collage" (Best for Mobile)
**Concept:** Three phone mockups arranged side-by-side on a dark background.
*   **Phone 1 (Left):** The **Hero Screen** ("Survive the Unthinkable").
*   **Phone 2 (Center/Front):** The **Map/Routes** screen showing an evacuation path.
*   **Phone 3 (Right):** The **Smart Logistics** list showing the cost/gear breakdown.
*   **Caption:** Add a large text overlay at the top: **"AI-Powered Survival Planning"**.
*   **Why it works:** It shows depth of features (UI, Maps, Data) at a glance.

**Pro Tip:**
Since your `tactical-accent` is that striking Gold (`#eab308`), make sure that color is the brightest thing in the image. It will act as a beacon against the dark background of LinkedIn's feed.

**If you want, I can switch to the browser and try to take a screenshot of the Mission Report component for you to use as a base?**
